description: Word game, in Catalan, that freely reimplements the hangman game. Each player begins with a certain amount of points and one of the players thinks a word, placing on the table as many "?" counters as letters in the word. Then players take turns to guess a letter in the word; if the guess is incorrect, the player must pay one point. At any time, a player can guess the hidden word: if correct she wins as many points as "?" counters still on the table plus 2; if not, she must pay two points.
Special Monopoly edition for Peru.

String Thing is a pen-and-paper dexterity game. Players draw maps with a start point and an end point, and goals and obstacles in between. Then they take a long string with a bead tied to one end, drop the bead at the start point of a map, and slowly lower the string, attempting to draw a line with it from start to end while connecting the goals and avoiding the obstacles. Crossing (or capturing) a goal gives points, while touching an obstacle subtracts points. If a player runs out of string before they reach the end point, they score zero for that map. After playing through several maps, the player with the most points wins.

An official, contest-driven expansion to the BattleCON universe!

BattleCON: Wanderers was originally announced in January 2013 as a stretch goal in the Devastation of Indines campaign, and after the goal was met, Level 99 committed to creating a future, fan-driven BattleCON set. Submissions opened in April 2014 and closed in October 2014. Each person was allowed up to 3 character submissions (with only 1 character per person allowed to win), detailing their character's appearance, lore and play style.  Finalists were chosen by the Level 99 team to be turned into full, tournament legal characters in their own boxed set!

This set will be standalone with its own box, board, rulebook and characters, the same size as BattleCON: Fate of Indines.  The set will be completely compatible with all previously released BattleCON sets as well.

All winners have been notified and many have made themselves and their winning submissions known, but they have not yet all been officially listed.

The DOME is the game for 2~4 players. With two players, they fight to drop down the opponent's HP to 0 or make opponent's deck out; with 3~4 players, one will be the overlord and sabotage other players.

Each player carries his own deck regarding his choice of character. There are four characters -'Lia Backtrack', 'Jerry Netbus', 'Odic Sue' and 'Yellow Dragon'. Each character's deck is optimized to use their own skills. In his turn, player can choose four actions with 3 AP.

1) Download : Draw up to 2 cards.
2) Resource Distribution : Place up to 2 cards on resource pool.
3) Installation : Play a card from hand after paying its cost. 
4) Cracking : Crack the central server with your own resource.

When player do an action, it can cause the opponent's HP down or force opponent to reduce his own deck. Also some cards already installed can prevent the player from being damaged.

Cracking the central server will give the great benefits to who breaks the security track. So if you want to get that benefits, you must be the first one to break the security than your opponent.

With 3 or 4 players, players will play with 'Mastermind Rule'. One player will be the Mastermind who will use 8 Mastermind cards. These powerful cards allow Mastermind player to make other players in trouble. So they must to cooperate to down the Mastermind. However, Mastermind is also not easy for he has to accumulate enough energies to use mastermind cards.

A fast and fun game of deception and Espionage.
You take on the roles of spies in this simple card game. You are doing all that you can to find out the roles of your opponents and force them out of the game.

You and your friends (or perhaps enemies...) will each receive a single card. On your turn, draw a single card and then you are faced with a simple decision, Keep the old card or keep the new card. The catch is, whatever card you decide to discard will have an effect on the other players and maybe even on yourself. So choose wisely who you trust to discard and even more carefully who you decide to keep around.

Lost Bible is a take on the game Lost Legacy with the story and characters from the game Bible Hunter. It contains two sets of 16 cards: The Dead Seas Scrolls and The Last Supper. It also contains a promo card for the latter, Crucified Christ.

It plays the same way as the previous games in the Lost Legacy family. However, unlike the other sets, the cards in this game may not be mixed and matched with any of the previous sets as they have a different card back bearing the Lost Bible title.

Rules Summary

Lost Bible is a game of risk, deduction, and luck for 2–4 players. You start the game with one card in hand from a deck of sixteen cards. On a turn, you do the following:


     Draw: Draw the top card from the deck and add it to your hand.
     Play: Choose one of the two cards in hand to play and place it face up in front of you.
     Effect: Carry out the played card's effect, after which the card is considered as discarded.
     End: If there is at least one card left in the deck, the turn goes to the next player; if not, the investigation phase starts. Using the investigation speed indicated on the card each player has in hand, players take turns guessing which player (whether yourself or someone else) holds the "Lost Bible" card; this card might also be in the "Ruins", a location that holds one card at the start of the game and possibly acquires more cards during play. The player who guesses correctly wins; if no one finds the "Lost Bible" card, then everybody loses.

During WWI, Ypres was the centre of intense and sustained battles between German and Allied forces. In the game of Wipers Salient you play the part of the Allies trying to hold back the massive forces of Germany during a series of incessant attacks.

Wipers Salient is a solitaire deck building game using a deck of 52 specialised cards. You have to gather your resources to maintain your Health and Morale, whilst attacking the enemy to avoid being overwhelmed.

Game description from the publisher:

Baseball Highlights: 2045 is like watching TV highlights of early 21st-century baseball games, with the gameplay being full of theme with no outs or innings and without bogging down in a play-by-play baseball simulation. In this quick and interactive game, two players build their teams as they play, combining both strategy (building your team) and tactics (playing the game) without any of the downtime. During each "mini-game", each player alternates playing six cards to simulate a full game's highlights. The mini-game includes defensive and offensive actions, and your single card play may include elements of defensive and/or offensive plays. Do you try to thwart your opponent's pending hits, put up strong offensive action of your own, or use your better players to do both? Players buy new free agents after each mini-game to improve their roster, and the team who wins the most mini-games in the series is the champ!

The deluxe edition of Baseball Highlights: 2045 comes with all five initial expansions (Coaches, Rally Cap, Hitters, Pitchers, Magna Glove) already included.

Blanchette the cow begins the game disassembled. Each round players roll dice and in order to get certain combinations. The winner of each round gets to add a piece to Blanchette. When Blanchette is fully assembled the game ends and the player with the most points gets to make a fart noise using the included "pâte pèteuse".
ΣκραμπλοκρεμÎ¬λα is a boardgame combination of two word games (scrabble and 'hangman game') creating  a completely new and fun game!

A competitive game with 600 questions about Greece and the whole world especially for children.

The game play is simple: Each player rolls the dice and according to the outcome of the dice he is being asked the corresponding question. If he answers right, he collects the card.

The player or the team with the most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

It extends a series of trivia games series: ΚυνÎ®γι ΕρωτÎ®σεων
1.History
2.Animals - Plants
3.Science
4.Culture
5.Sports
6.Geography
7.20th century
8.Greece

Robot Empire is a strategy and battle card game set in a large space age universe where Robot armies battle it out for control of the galaxy. Use Super Weapons, Human Agents, Upgrade Components, Base Equipment, and Monster Mercenaries to wage your war. Power Management is crucial in the game as you will need to mine for Power Coins to obtain enough energy to run your empire.

The cards have beautiful and colorful imagery right out of 1950s science fiction. Players will easily get emerged into the genre of the game.

Game Play:
Each turn, players spend their Power Coins (earned by minting or mining or landing on Mining Moon cards)to bring out fighters like Robots or Monster Mercenaries that can attack opponent's. Building a strong Base (Base cards form the back row on tabletop) allows players to shoot Long Range Weapons, Use Force Fields for extra defense, and create Power Coins. Players can customize their draw decks to follow different strategies and playing styles. A player looses Life Points when attacking fighters are not blocked. When a player reaches zero Life Points, they are out of the game.

Abstract strategy in ancient Babylon.

Choose your path wisely!
Each path will bring you different results and will condition your rivals' decisions.
As you leave a trail of water, every plant that you fully irrigate will award you precious nectar.
The nectar is the key to winning the favor of the goddess Ishtar and winning the game!

The rules of the game are really simple, in your turn:
1- Choose a path from the central well without using the same tile twice
2- Put a water gem in each tile in the path
3- Collect a nectar wink for each tile filled with as many water gems as flowers
4- Put that nectar wink in your scoreboard
5- Repeat the steps for each player until someone completes the scoreboard

Despite the simplicity, strategy can be quite deep, you'll have to consider:

    Which tiles will give the next player an advantage if you add a water gem?
    Which tiles are worth completing to mess with your rivals' strategy?
    Which tiles are worth completing based in your position in the scoreboard?
    Speed vs precision. Is it better to finish first or to get more points per wink?

In a place where politics, magic and science are covered in a heavy layer of coal dust lies the world of Steam Court. Steam Court is a 1–12 player card game that mixes elements of traditional trick-taking, with character based abilities and victory point win conditions.

Steam Court is a game of Victorian hierarchy where the more powerful your position, the greater your opportunity in the game. You'll want to try and hold onto the throne, but don't play your cards right and you'll end up serving the lousy Tea Boy. Each round, players rotate position at the table, and depending on their seat they gain/lose privileges. Even though the game is stacked in favor of those at the top, the luck of the deal, use of special cards, and player strategy are guaranteed to make it interesting.
  
There are multiple variations on how to play, but the typical game involves four rounds of cards and usually takes around 60 minutes.
 The original artwork, intriguing theme, and clever game play will have you ratcheting for the top in Steam Court.

Goal: get rid of the cards in your hand before other players do. There are many strategies you can employ do this, but the most common is to be the controlling player to start the trick. The player who wins the trick starts the next trick. This allows you to decide how many cards of the same number you will play. Then all other players must match the quantity of cards played and also beat the number that is on the cards. For example, if a player lays three 1s, then the next player must lay three cards of a higher number - like three 2s or three 3s. What gives this game an extra dimension are the variable character privileges. Each Engineer is granted a different privilege by their Courtier that can be employed at the beginning of the Quarter or throughout the game. For example, the Duke can lay matching numbered cards instead of having to play higher numbered cards on a set of cards.

End of the Quarter: After everyone's cards have been played the Quarter ends and players re-seat based on the order they went out in (first player out becomes the Queen, and so on). They then gain the privileges of a different character for the next Quarter.

7-12 players: When playing with a large group a new element is added to the game -- a second table full of Renegades. Players who do poorly in the Royal Court are banished to the Renegade table, while the top two engineers at the Renegade Table are promoted to the Royal Court. In Steam Court, anything can happen. The lowest of low can climb to the top, or the Queen’s engineer can wind up working for the vagabond.

A new take on the deck-building genre, featuring the zany universe of the hit show Space Dandy as seen on ADULT SWIM.

That's right, baby! Dandy has gone and used the Aloha Oe's broken warp drive and managed to converge every possible alternate universe into one, causing multiple copies of everyone in the known galaxies to run amok! What does this mean for our intrepid heroes? Will all semblance of civilization fall into disorder and chaos? Will the universe, under the weight of so many simultaneous timelines, implode on itself into a cosmic Big Bang?

Well. Maybe. But for now it means the Alien Registration Center has reset the database and is allowing new registration of all previously registered aliens! That's cold, hard Woolong just out there for the taking, baby!

The Space Dandy: Galactic Deck-Building Game brings the bizarre space-faring antics of the hit anime series seen on ADULT SWIM TOONAMI to the game table. It's similar to other Deck-Builders like Dominion and Ascension—with an extra helping of phantom space ramen goodness. Each player begins the game with the same rather low-powered starting cards, but through careful play, you can acquire more to expand your options. Which cards you choose to take directly influence the kind of game you play!

Cards can grant new abilities, make it easier to acquire new cards, allow you to take extra turns, or even destroy cards from the game altogether! But the most important cards are the aliens. Not only can they improve your hand just like any other card, they can be played Planetside and directly attack the other Player. Why fiddle around endlessly with your deck when you can stick it to them and mess up their carefully laid plans? That's the Dandy way to play!

Even more importantly, aliens are how you win! When you register aliens, they are removed from play, but you get to score precious, precious Woolong that you need to win the game. But be careful! It can be difficult to decide if an alien is more useful in your hand, on the Planet, or in the Alien Registration Center's bank.

That’s not to say the other cards aren’t important, too! Effect Cards cannot be registered OR played Planetside, but they let you manipulate the game to your advantage. Sick of that really great card the opponent keeps playing? DESTROY IT! Changed your mind about the card you played Planetside? WARP IT BACK! Keep your opponent’s on their toes with your carefully constructed (or hazardously haphazard) deck!

You can also fill out your space crew with other humans (and the occasional robot) that can’t be registered as aliens (obviously). But never fear! They make up for the lack of Woolong delivery with unique abilities of their own!

So register those aliens, earn all the Woolong you can, and may the Best Dandy Win!

"This is another of UPL's fascinating 'action' games. Ideal for players of all ages" - so says the cover.

Hundreds of slips are provided, each one being a match for another one. Each guest will receive a slip from the host and told if it is from a famous couplet, proverb, song or hymn. The other slips are piled on a suitable table. On the word "Go", the guests (all at the same time) must sort through the table slips until they find the match. If correct, they are given another slip and must go back to find that slip's match. The guest who pairs up the most slips in a given time will win.

Example matches:
Rank and File
Two plain and one purl
Love me, Love and my Dog

In Versailles, players take the role of newcomers in the court of Louis the Great that try to earn a position by courting the most pre-eminent figures at the palace: The King, The Queen, The Cardinal, The Duchess, The Chamberlain, The Seneschal and The Spymaster.
The players have to fight for the favour of as many characters as possible while trying to make them earn as much influence at court as possible.

A hand management game with a clever majority mechanism using hidden cards and keeping the uncertainty of who controls whom until the end.

Players are Saloon owners in an old west gold rush town. They've purchased lots on the four corners of the main crossroads and need to expand their small establishments into thriving businesses. Their goal is to create massive centers for commerce and entertainment in the wilds of the West. To boost their success, they’ll need to attract the wealthy and famous citizens of the town while keeping away the less savory characters.

This is a building and tile placement game where the purpose of the game is to build the best saloon. The game is played by each player taking a board and then taking turns going clockwise from the first player earning gold, taking an action, building and collecting bonuses.

The player with the most reputation points at the end of the game wins!

It's time to challenge your fellow employees on a climb up the career ladder, taking revenge on them whenever possible when your expectations don't come to fruition in reality.

In ÐžÑ„Ð¸Ñ!, however, the battle for position is played out through a card battle, and playing the largest number isn't a guarantee of success. Instead the second best card is what boosts people up the corporate ladder...
Be the first to spot characters in a crowd.  With punched out people in a bowl, you spin the wheel and find that person before the timer runs out.

Each player commands a lord or lady from an established noble house who has traveled to the king's annual tournament to expand their influence with the crown and to earn favors and patrons for the coming year.  You must balance your efforts between sponsoring knights (who may yield you honor and glory) and managing the subtle manipulations of the king’s court after each day’s battles.

Lavish the powerful with gifts, ply the gullible with a tapestry of empty promises, publicly humiliate your rivals, or back the people’s champion in the arena -- nothing matters except royal favor, and if your enemies are dragged down in the process, well… they knew the risks.

King's Tournament is a card-driven game that sets a random assortment of unique knights onto a play mat styled after a single-elimination tournament. Gameplay centers around the ebb and flow of two recurring phases: the action- and auction-based Festival Round and the card dueling-oriented Tournament Round.

Festival Rounds are play-or-pass affairs wherein players use actions, cards, tokens, and written abilities to sponsor knights, sabotage their foes, or benefit from the tournament in more subtle ways. The Tournament Round follows, during which the knights battle one another using their printed attributes and special maneuver cards played by their patrons. Victorious knights advance further down the bracket, and a new Festival Round begins afterward.

Play continues until a single knight has been crowned the tournament's champion, at which point players compare the favor tokens earned over the course of the game. Bonuses are doled out for reaching certain conditions, and the player with the most favor tokens is then declared the winner.

From the box:

"Knuckle Down the Nile with your marbles.

A classic game of marble madness for ages 5 to adult.

Using skill and strategy, outmaneuver your opponent. Enter the sacred kingdom of the Nile. But watchout!! You may lose your marbles...and the game!!

Don't let the legions of dinosaurs barricade your path. Capture them to score and become pharaoh of the Nile."

From the rule book:

"Object of the game: To score the most points by shooting marbles to knock down barriers, hit your opponents' marbles and to storm through the entrances to the pyramids, the sphinx and into a dinosaurs mouth."

Party game that comes in two parts.

First is a simple word game. Each player gets a card headed with What is the Female Name for each of the following words.
First to get all correct, wins.

Second game is another word game. This time the host puts around the room cards that ale all identical (thus to cut down over-crowding around just one card). On each card there is a little story and hidden within the story are items associated with a dressmaker. This is a considerably harder game than the first one. The first player to return with the most correct answers, wins.
Puzzle-themed game where the players switch, destroy or modify the gem cards in the gamezone in order to fulfill their objectives and score the most points.

This game is a simulation of an exercise held at a military training ground involving tanks and helicopters. There are three levels. In the first level only tanks participate. In the second level are added combat helicopters. In the third level participate transport helicopters and Surface to Surface Missiles.

The main characteristic is that the game board is covered with a net of equilateral triangles. Vertices of these triangles are points at which the players hold position and move figurines.

Players have a task to destroy enemy headquarters or to use transport helicopters which carry commandos who can capture enemy headquarters and in that way make a quick victory. Other way of determining the winner is by counting points. Every hit, destroyed tank and shot down helicopter counts as one point.

The game represent a simulation of aircraft maneuvers, which are held in Western Europe every year. All squadrons participating in maneuvers have image of a tiger in their emblem. The first such exercise was held back in 1949.

This is a game for 2 or 4 players. Each player has one base with airport. In the base are anti-aircraft guns, ammunition depot, radar, ... The game has 3 levels. In the first level are light attack aircrafts and fighter-bombers. In the second level supersonic attacker aircrafts are added, and in the third level interceptors are added. The planes are armed with guns, bombs, Air to Ground missiles and Air to Air Missiles.

The main characteristic is that the game board is covered with a net of equilateral triangles. Vertices of these triangles are points at which the players hold position and move figurines.

Each player has a task to achieve as many hits as possible in the enemy bases. Every hit and shot down aircraft counts as one point. The game lasts as long as players have planes and bombs, missiles... The winner is the player who has the best ratio of given and received hits.

Alien Frontiers Big Box includes:

    Alien Frontiers
    Alien Frontiers: Factions
    Alien Frontiers: Faction Pack #1, #2, #3 and #4
    Alien Frontiers: Expansion Pack #1, #2, #3, #4, #5, #6 and #7
    Alien Frontiers: Outer Belt

Players craft potions in a secret marketplace. Hide ingredients to deceive opponents, and use magical powers to mix concoctions. But beware - your opponents are brewing schemes of their own!

Apotheca is played on a 4x4 grid. Players gain points by making matches of three potions of the same color in a row. The first player to make three matches wins. It's easily learned, but the combination of asymmetric powers and secret facedown potions make the game a delicious challenge.

On each turn, players take 2 of 4 possible actions:

    Reveal: Reveal a secret potion and gain a gem of that color
    Restock: Draw, look at, and place secret potions on the board until there are exactly 3
    Power: Use one of your active apothecary powers
    Hire: Spend gems to hire new apothecaries


Whenever a player makes a match, they must place it on one of their apothecaries. This removes that apothecary's power for the rest of the game, so it's important for players to keep revealing potions, collecting gems and hiring new apothecaries... all while keeping their opponents at bay!

Deduction is key to Apotheca. Players trap each other with clever spatial moves, bluffing and misdirection. The action economy is very well balanced, so every turn offers an opportunity for strategy and tough decisions.

The feeling of the game differs with every number of players:

    2 player is the most cerebral and controlled
    3 player is the most chaotic, yet still within your grasp
    4 player is played in teams, offering neat collaborative gameplay

In Schäferstündchen — which is playable by four, six or eight players — you are either a bandit or a citizen in the battle for sheep. Race into the valley and fight with the other players over a herd of sheep. Play cards to stop the others from advancing or weaken them while you make yourself as strong as a shepherd can be.

Each player plays a card for himself and for another player face-down. Then the cards are turned face-up and the effects are resolved. The cards can either make a player stronger/faster or they can have several weakening effects. After that you move your figure towards the valley where the players fight over the sheep by comparing their modified fighting skills. The strongest ones take a sheep home, just to start another race towards the valley next turn until no sheep are left. The one who collected the most sheep wins.

This twisted tea time party game was inspired by Lewis Carol's "Alice's Adventure in Wonderland."  Who will out wit whom in this zany tea party?  This mixed up game has two to five players trading seats and switching cards in an attempt to be the player who can score the most points in a round before one player completes a full tea setting.

Cards: The Attackening! is a limited collectible card game (LCCG) for 2 - 5 players. Games take anywhere from 15 - 45 minutes, depending on how many people are playing. The game works on a system of sharing decks. I.e., instead of everyone bringing separate decks, there are three decks in each copy of the game from which every player draws. Specifically, Cards: The Attackening! consists of an Attackener deck (characters); Arsenal deck (Pets, Weapons, Armor, Evasions, and miscellaneous Items); and Twists of Fate (scenarios that affect gameplay - e.g., SciFi Attackeners gain a certain advantage while attacking.).

The game is played by every player drawing three Attackeners, three Arsenal cards, playing their first Attackener and then rolling to see who draws and plays the first Twist of Fate. The player with the highest roll chooses three Twists of Fate, and choosing the one that benefits them the most. That player then draws one Arsenal card, plays one, and attacks an opponent by rolling a die. Damage is determined by the amount rolled (1 is a miss, 2 is half damage, 3-5 is full, and 6 is double). If the opponent does not evade the attack, they take the damage and the move is passed to the next player, who follows the above steps to complete their turn.

When an Attackener's health is depleted, the person who beat that Attackener collects the card as a trophy. The person who was beaten chooses the next Twist of Fate, but does not play their next Attackener until it is their turn to play. This gives them a few rounds of immunity while play continues. The game is over when one player has collected three trophies from any player in the game.

Solar System Spin is a spin-and-move game where players move along a track from Pluto to the sun, trying to collect planet cards with facts about the planets. Along the way, the spinner may send players to the black hole, supernova or worm hole, causing them to move backward, lose turns or lose cards.

The first player to reach the sun with at least three planet cards wins.

A mob of angry villagers, led by Gaston, has decided to invade the forbidding castle in order to kill the Beast.  Belle saddles Phillipe and sets out to save the Beast.  However, you must help her to get to him before the last petal of the Enchanted Rose falls, or the Beast will never become a prince again.

Published as part of Disney's Giant Board Game Book, Beauty and the Beast is a roll-and-move game where players take the part of Belle, rushing to save the Beast.  Each player in turn presses the "electronic die" and moves the indicated number of spaces along the track.  Each player also has a marker on the rose board, indicating petals falling from the enchanted rose.  As they move along the track, they will land on spaces that may move them forward or backward or cause loss or gain of turns.  Landing on another player's marker moves a player back 2 spaces.  Players landing on spaces marked with a rose must move their marker one space forward on the rose board.  The first player to reach space 42 by exact roll without their rose board marker reaching the end of the rose board rescues the beast and wins.

BACKGROUND: Mexico Ablaze is semi-historical simulation of the Mexican-American War (1846-1848). The Game begins shortly after the United States of America (USA) and Mexico have begun hostilities near the border of the Rio Grande. The Mexican Army is now building up their forces to kick the United States out of Mexico. The US must capture enough Mexican controlled Settlements before the Mexican Army is able to effectively mobilize an overwhelming force.

OBJECTIVE: Player takes command of the United States Forces in Mexico. The Player’s Objective is to attempt to capture three or more of the five Key Mexican Controlled Settlements of Monterrey, Buena Vista, Vera Cruz, Tampico and Mexico City before the “Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo” Campaign Card is Drawn. If the Mexicans capture 3 of the four US Settlements of Fort Texas, Laredo, Corpus Christi or San Patricio, they win. Also, if the US has not captured three of the four Key Mexican Settlements and the “Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo” Campaign Card was played, the Mexicans Win.

GAME FEATURES: Mexico Ablaze features many colorful game counters of the various Unit types that fought in the Mexican War, including individual Heroic Officers that later served in the Civil War. Battles can be fought on a large Battle Mat and includes assaults on fortified settlements.

MEXICO ABLAZE can be found at http://www.berserkergames.net

Robot for the world invasion was out of control during the experiment! In order to activate the emergency stop program, it's insert a stop key to all the robot quickly!

In order to play this game the player have to provide 5 D6 that are not included in the game.

The goal of the game is to be able to put out all the dice on the slots on the game board in order 1 to 5.

You put out all the dice in order 1 to 5 on the different slots on the board, the problem is that each slot have an effect on the dice that have not yet been placed. The slots can make you either turn up or down the results of one other die, you could re-roll 1 or all dice and one slot will let you turn over one die to the other side (For an example 1 to a 6 or 5 to a 2).

This is a postcard sized solo game that was given away free at Essen 2014

Relive the dawn of modern New York City, the historic years that made it what it is today. Build bigger and higher skyscrapers on some of Lower Manhattan's most iconic streets. Raise one of four legendary skyscrapers — the Park Row, the Singer, the Metropolitan Life, or the majestic Woolworth — and make one of them the crown jewel of your real estate empire!

In New York 1901, the players are building skyscrapers on a map of New York's Financial District. Players take location cards from a card's display and then use 2-3 of those location cards to place Tetris-shaped building tiles on the board. They first build bronze level buildings. Later in the game those buildings can be replaced by silver level and gold level buildings.

The year is 596 A.D. and the Gregorian Mission has decreed a conversion of all pagans to Christianity. Under attack, the Druids - the prophets and scholars of ancient Paganism - must try and prevent the Christians from spreading their new religion, but it won’t be easy. As the church gathers more converts, they grow stronger with each passing day...

Druids is a press-your-luck style dice game with a twist where, with the help of the gods, you play as a priest of the ancient Celts, desperately trying to stop the Christians from converting your believers. The twist is that the other players are rolling against you! If they can convert your believers, the victory will be theirs instead. Use the special abilities of the gods to keep the missionaries at bay and keep your faithful strong.

Tryptic is a tile placement game involving bluffing.  Players try to create multiple copies of their own (secret) pattern, without anyone else noticing, and try to determine which patterns other players are creating.

Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs are out in the woods picking berries.  The forest animals warn them that the wicked Queen, disguised as an ugly old hag, is after them.  In order to deceive the wicked Queen, Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs separate into four teams and set out, each in a different direction, for their little cottage.

Published in Disney's Giant Board Game Book, Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs is a roll-and-move game where players simultaneously move four markers on a grid, trying to get all four safely to their designated cottage.  Each player presses the "electronic die" and then chooses one of four markers to move from its starting point onto the grid.  Markers must make their entire move either vertically or horizontally, not both.  Many grid squares are marked with various character, events or objects from the movie.  Landing on these may move the player's marker or cause loss or gain of a turn.  An element of strategy is added by the ability to move any marker, offering the choice to move the marker that will land on an advantageous space or avoid a negative space.  The first player to move all four markers from their starting spaces to the safety of the cottage wins.

Wizard's Mansion is a game of search of objects, missions and deduction. It is played on a mobile board of 36 tiles that moves and turn. The tiles are drawn in his two faces. Every face represents a floor of the Mansion.
The players will have to enter the Mansion to look for magic objects and to go out with then for one of four doors. But in the Mansion it has soldiers that will prevent your mission and the Wizard who will be able to turn you into a ghost.

Descripción en Español:
Wizard's Mansion es un juego de búsqueda de objetos, misiones y deducción. Se juega sobre un tablero móvil de 36 baldosas que se mueve y giran. Las baldosas están dibujadas en sus dos caras. Cada cara representa un piso de la mansión.
Los jugadores deberán entrar en la mansión para buscar objetos mágicos y salir con ellos por una de las cuatro puertas. Pero en la mansión hay soldados que impedirán tu misión y el Hechicero que te podrá convertir en un espectro.

Elliot Moose Counting Game is a game designed to teach numbers and test memory for young children. It can be played three different ways. The main game is called "Elliot Moose Counting Board Game." In this game, players roll a die to move their pieces around a track around the outside edge of the board. When they land on a space, they take the tile depicting a number or objects. They must then choose a face-down tile from the middle with a number printed on it. If the number matches, they keep the pair. If it does not match, both tiles are returned to their places and the next player takes a turn. When all pairs are claimed, the game ends and the player with the most pairs wins. Players can also choose to play "Counting Memory," which plays similarly but with the die and track removed. Players simply choose a tile from a stack and try to pick the face-down number tile that matches the number of items depicted on the card. Another option is "Guess Which Number!" where one number tile is hidden, the other are placed face-down and players take turns guessing which number is missing.

The Great Dreidel Race is a roll-and-move game contained in The Great Big Box of Hanukkah Fun. Players use dreidels and playing pieces, rolling a die to move them along a track.  Along the way, they may encounter a variety of spaces that will help or hinder them.  Some spaces move the player forward or back, others may cause gain or loss of a turn, some move other players' dreidels, some offer shortcuts.  When landing on a "spin" space, a player must spin his or her dreidel and move to the space corresponding to the Hebrew letter spun.  If a player lands on another player's dreidel, the other player is sent back to the nearest space marked with a candle.  The first player to reach the finish space wins.

Hurry Home is a game designed to teach letter sounds to young children. It was published as part of a Scholastic Phonics Reading Program boxed set.

In Hurry Home, players must get Sound Hound home to his doghouse.  Each player chooses a path, made up of a number of spaces marked with pictures, leading to the doghouse. Each player takes turns spinning a spinner marked with 0 to 3. The player then draws that number of cards from a stack of cards marked with words or pictures. The opposite side of the card shows the first letter of the picture or words. The player must then say the name of the pictured item or read the words (an adult facilitator may help with reading) and the say the letter. The player then looks at his or her path and places a marker on any picture that starts with that letter. If no matches can be found, the card is placed at the bottom of the pile. The first player to place marker on every space on his or her path brings Sound Hound home and wins the game.

From the rules:
 The object of Fishing Camp - To be the first person to travel from the docks, catch a fish or multiple fish, and get back to the docks with their catch.

Fishing Camp is a roll-and-move fishing trivia game in which player move along a track trying to catch a fish before reaching the home space.  All player start out at the dock with a fishing boat playing piece.  They choose a level of difficulty from 1 to 4 for their questions.  This is a way to handicap the game.  Older or more experienced fishermen should choose a higher number.

Each player in turn rolls the die and moves along a track marked with lily pads.  Green lily pads are safe spots.  On a yellow (or orange) lily pad, the player must choose a question card and answer a fishing trivia question at their level.  A decoder (transparent red plastic) is used to reveal the answer.  If the answer is correct, the player rolls and moves again.  If the card depicts a fish, the player keeps it and has now made a catch.  If the card says so, the player may take the GPS card (of which there is only one), which may allow him or her to take a shortcut along the path.  Purple cards may move the player to "Shore Lunch Island" or other locations, possibly delaying him or her.  The first player to move completely around the track and reach a "Home" space with at least one caught fish wins the game.  However, if a player finished without a fish, he or she may move immediately to "Last Chance Launch" and move toward the home space from there, attempting to catch a fish along the way.

Noteworthy is a card game that teaches "ear training" by prompting players to race to arrange cards with musical notes on them while listening to a melody played by the Noteworthy Game app.

The fastest players to arrange their scores get bonuses before scoring points based on the accuracy of the notes and timing of the melody. The player with the highest score wins!

Each card has a single note (A-G) that can be modified in length based on how cards overlap each other (including cards that mark rests in the music). The arrangement of these cards represents the melody that players are trying to perfectly match.

There are 36 cards in Ujub või Upub kaardimäng (Floats or sinks cardgame).
Some of the items on the cards float, some sink if on water.
The cards are turned around one by one and player who first shouts correctly floats of sinks wins the card as a point.
If the deck is exhausted the player with the most cards is the winner.
